name: Fantasy Worlds
description: Epic quotes from beloved fantasy books, films, and TV adaptations.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: Not all those who wander are lost.
quotes.source: The Fellowship of the Ring (1954)
quotes.notes: From the poem about Aragorn. Often quoted independently as a travel or life philosophy motto.

quotes.content: All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.
quotes.source: The Fellowship of the Ring (1954)
quotes.notes: Gandalf's advice to Frodo in Moria. One of Tolkien's most quoted philosophical passages.

quotes.content: Even the smallest person can change the course of the future.
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
quotes.notes: Film addition by Fran Walsh and Philippa Boyens. Cate Blanchett's delivery made it iconic.

quotes.content: You shall not pass!
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
quotes.notes: Gandalf confronting the Balrog. In the book it's 'You cannot pass!' The film version became more famous.

quotes.content: My precious.
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)
quotes.notes: Gollum's obsessive phrase for the Ring. Serkis' motion-capture performance revolutionized the technology.

quotes.content: A wizard is never late. He arrives precisely when he means to.
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
quotes.notes: Gandalf's response to Frodo about his timing. Sets up Gandalf's enigmatic character.

quotes.content: There is only one Lord of the Ring.
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
quotes.notes: Gandalf rejecting Saruman's offer of alliance. Establishes the Ring's singular corrupting power.

quotes.content: Winter is coming.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones (2011)
quotes.notes: Stark family words warning of coming hardship. Became one of TV's most recognized phrases.

quotes.content: When you play the game of thrones, you win or you die.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones, S1E7 (2011)
quotes.notes: Cersei warning Ned Stark about the stakes of power. Defines the show's brutal political world.

quotes.content: A Lannister always pays his debts.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones (2011)
quotes.notes: Lannister family saying. Used for both financial reliability and threats of revenge.

quotes.content: The night is dark and full of terrors.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones (2011)
quotes.notes: Red Priestess prayer to R'hllor, the Lord of Light. Became the show's ominous catchphrase.

quotes.content: Valar morghulis. All men must die.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones (2012)
quotes.notes: High Valyrian greeting of the Faceless Men. Response: 'Valar dohaeris' (All men must serve).

quotes.content: I drink and I know things.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones, S6E2 (2016)
quotes.notes: Tyrion's self-deprecating job description. Became one of the show's most merchandised quotes.

quotes.content: Chaos isn't a pit. Chaos is a ladder.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones, S3E6 (2013)
quotes.notes: Littlefinger revealing his philosophy of exploiting instability. Defines his scheming character.

quotes.content: Hold the door!
quotes.source: Game of Thrones, S6E5 (2016)
quotes.notes: Revealed origin of Hodor's name. The episode's tragic twist shocked and devastated viewers.

quotes.content: You know nothing, Jon Snow.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones (2012)
quotes.notes: Ygritte's recurring phrase to Jon. Became a pop culture catchphrase and meme.

quotes.content: Fear cuts deeper than swords.
quotes.source: A Game of Thrones by George R.R. Martin (1996)
quotes.notes: Arya's sword instructor's wisdom. Part of her internal mantra for survival.

quotes.content: The man who passes the sentence should swing the sword.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones, S1E1 (2011)
quotes.notes: Ned's lesson to Bran about justice and responsibility. Establishes Stark honor.

quotes.content: I am the blood of the dragon.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones (2011)
quotes.notes: Daenerys asserting her Targaryen heritage. Foreshadows her growing power and eventual transformation.

quotes.content: Dracarys!
quotes.source: Game of Thrones, S3E4 (2013)
quotes.notes: High Valyrian command meaning 'dragonfire.' Daenerys' first devastating use of her dragons.

quotes.content: The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills.
quotes.source: The Wheel of Time by Robert Jordan (1990)
quotes.notes: Central philosophy of the series about fate and destiny. The Pattern cannot be changed.

quotes.content: Duty is heavier than a mountain, death lighter than a feather.
quotes.source: The Wheel of Time by Robert Jordan (1990)
quotes.notes: Borderlander saying that Lan lives by. Reflects the warrior culture's sense of honor.

quotes.content: The only way to live is to die.
quotes.source: Mistborn by Brandon Sanderson (2006)
quotes.notes: Kelsier's paradoxical wisdom about giving everything for a cause. His philosophy shapes the rebellion.

quotes.content: Strength before weakness. Journey before destination.
quotes.source: The Stormlight Archive by Brandon Sanderson (2010)
quotes.notes: Core oath of the Knights Radiant. 'Life before death' precedes these lines in the full oath.

quotes.content: I will protect those who cannot protect themselves.
quotes.authorName: The Second Ideal of the Windrunners
quotes.source: The Stormlight Archive by Brandon Sanderson (2010)
quotes.notes: Kaladin's oath that unlocks greater power. Each order has different Ideals.

quotes.content: Words are pale shadows of forgotten names.
quotes.source: The Name of the Wind by Patrick Rothfuss (2007)
quotes.notes: Kvothe's philosophy about the power of true names. Central to the magic system.

quotes.content: It's the questions we can't answer that teach us the most.
quotes.source: The Name of the Wind by Patrick Rothfuss (2007)
quotes.notes: Kvothe reflecting on learning and wisdom. Fits his scholar-musician-adventurer character.

quotes.content: A reader lives a thousand lives before he dies.
quotes.source: A Dance with Dragons by George R.R. Martin (2011)
quotes.notes: Jojen's observation about the power of reading and stories. Meta-commentary on fiction.

quotes.content: There's some good in this world, Mr. Frodo, and it's worth fighting for.
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)
quotes.notes: Sam's hopeful speech at Osgiliath. Film addition that crystallizes the trilogy's themes.

quotes.content: I can't carry it for you, but I can carry you.
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)
quotes.notes: Sam carrying Frodo up Mount Doom. Represents friendship and loyalty at their purest.

quotes.content: One does not simply walk into Mordor.
quotes.source: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)
quotes.notes: Boromir explaining Mordor's dangers at the Council of Elrond. Became one of the internet's earliest memes.

quotes.content: What is dead may never die.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones (2012)
quotes.notes: Ironborn religious phrase about the Drowned God. 'But rises again, harder and stronger.'

quotes.content: The things I do for love.
quotes.source: Game of Thrones, S1E1 (2011)
quotes.notes: Jaime before pushing Bran from the tower. Introduces his morally complex character.

quotes.content: It is our choices that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities.
quotes.source: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets by J.K. Rowling (1998)
quotes.notes: Dumbledore's wisdom to Harry about character and identity. Central theme of the series.

quotes.content: After all this time? Always.
quotes.source: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows by J.K. Rowling (2007)
quotes.notes: Snape's revelation about his love for Lily Potter. The series' most emotional twist.
